guideline.MAIN_SCORE_GOOD3: ! The risk score will increase as threats, network violations, vulnerabilities, suspicious processes or file system activity is detected.
guideline.MAIN_SCORE_NOT_GOOD2: , please review the individual risk scores and follow the recommendations to reduce the overall risk.
guideline.MAIN_SCORE_ERR: Security risk score is not available, as it is impacted by some error
guideline.SERVICE_EXPOSURE: Services in discover mode allow and whitelist all connections and processes. Review rules for these services under Policy, and consider switching stable services to Monitor/Protect mode to minimize risk.
guideline.INGRESS_EGRESS: Please review all Services and Pods with exposure, and consider adding appropriate rules to protect these services/pods. To reduce the risk score, make sure they are in a Monitor/Protect mode and are not generating violations or threat events.
guideline.VUL_EXPLOIT: To reduce the vulnerability risk score remove as many high CVEs as possible and make sure any vulnerable service/pods are in Monitor/Protect mode. Monitor/Protect mode reduces risk by detecting suspicious connections or processes generated by exploited vulnerabilities.
guideline.AUTO_SCAN_OFF: Vulnerability auto-scanning is OFF. Please turn Auto-Scan. Moving services into Monitor/Protect mode will also reduce risk.

panel_title.SERVICE_CONTAINER_POLICY_MODE: Policy Mode of Services and Pods
panel_title.PROTOCOL_APPS_IN_POLICY: Application Protocols Detected and Protected by Layer 7 Network Rules

comments.SAFE: Congrats! All your services are under policy protection perfectly! Please keep it.
comments.CAUTION_SERVICE: Services in Discover mode are still learning and white-listing network behavior and will not have network segmentation turned on.
comments.CAUTION_POD: Move services into Monitor or Protect mode as soon as possible after reviewing Network Rules.

message.DISABLE_AUTOSCAN_CONFIRM: If auto scan is disabled, future vulnerability will not be found immediately.

exposure.txt1: Ingress and Egress exposure and risk summarizes external connections for the cluster. Ingress shows incoming connections by application protocol from outside the cluster, and Egress shows connections by application protocol from pods to any destination outside the cluster. The Mode is the protection mode which the service is in and Action shows allow if a network rule allows it, or deny if it was a violation.
exposure.txt2: How to Use It: Review ingress and egress connections to make sure allowed ones should be allowed, and investigate any that show deny. If shown as a deny but it should be allowed, review the network rules to whitelist the connections.

criticalEvent.txt1: Critical Run-Time Security Events show totals for Critical and Warning level events. Only critical run-time security events are summarized.
criticalEvent.txt2: How to Use It: High volumes of critical events could indicate an attack or a misconfigured service. Investigate to determine if they are coming from the same service or namespace. Updates of services with new application or process behavior could be generating security events and require adding new whitelist rules, or moving the service to Discover mode to learn them.

top_security_events.txt1: Top security events by Source shows the containers or pods with the most network security events originating from that pods or containers. Security events are including network based detection of suspicious payloads or connections such as DDoS or sql injection etc, network segmentation (whitelist rule) violations, suspicious process or file system incidents.
top_security_events.txt2: How to Use It: Review containers with security events to see if there are following phenomena:
top_security_events.txt2_1: 1. The container has been exploited to start generating attacks (lateral, east-west movement). If yes, you need to fix them.
top_security_events.txt2_2: 2. The containers generating violations to see if they have been compromised and are being used to expand laterally or attempt egress. If connections should be allowed, add a whitelist rule for them.
top_security_events.txt2_3: 3. Often a compromised or hacked pod will have multiple process and file system incidents as the hacker tries to install malicious code or vulnerable packages and/or start suspicious processes. Pods can be quarantined or a packet capture started by NeuVector.
top_security_events.txt3: Top security events by Destination shows the containers or pods with the most network security events hitting that container. Security events are including network based detection of suspicious payloads or connections such as DDoS or sql injection etc, pods or containers with the most unauthorized connections to them (destination), egress connections out of the cluster which are suspicious are shown as external violations, suspicious process or file system incidents.
top_security_events.txt4: How to Use It: Review containers with security events to see if there are following phenomena:
top_security_events.txt4_1: 1. The container has been under attack and if the attack has succeeded or damaged the container. If yes, you need to fix them.
top_security_events.txt4_2: 2. Top destinations to determine if unauthorized connections are attempted attacks, especially if originating from one client container or from external (ingress). If connection should be allowed, add a whitelist rule for it.
top_security_events.txt4_3: 3. Often a compromised or hacked pod will have multiple process and file system incidents as the hacker tries to install malicious code or vulnerable packages and/or start suspicious processes. Pods can be quarantined or a packet capture started by NeuVector.

top_thread.txt1: Top threats by Source shows the containers or pods with the most network Threats originating from that container.. Threats are network based detection of suspicious payloads or connections such as DDoS, sql injection etc.
top_thread.txt2: How to Use It: Review containers with high threat levels to see if the container has been exploited to start generating attacks (lateral, east-west movement).
top_thread.txt3: Top threats by Destination shows the containers or pods with the most network Threats hitting that container. Threats are network based detection of suspicious payloads or connections such as DDoS, sql injection etc.
top_thread.txt4: How to Use It: Review containers with high threat levels to see if the container has been under attack and if the attack has succeeded or damaged the container.

top_violation.txt1: Top Violations by Client shows network segmentation (whitelist rule) violations originating from pods or containers.
top_violation.txt2: How to Use It: Review containers generating violations to see if they have been compromised and are being used to expand laterally or attempt egress. If connections should be allowed, add a whitelist rule for them.
top_violation.txt3: Top Violations by Server shows pods or containers with the most unauthorized connections to them (destination). Egress connections out of the cluster which are suspicious are shown as external violations.
top_violation.txt4: How to Use It: Review top destinations to determine if unauthorized connections are attempted attacks, especially if originating from one client container or from external (ingress). If connection should be allowed, add a whitelist rule for it.

top_incident_pod.txt1: Top incidents by pods shows suspicious process or file system incidents sorted by most incidents by pods.
top_incident_pod.txt2: How to Use It: Often a compromised or hacked pod will have multiple process and file system incidents as the hacker tries to install malicious code or vulnerable packages and/or start suspicious processes. Pods can be quarantined or a packet capture started by NeuVector.

top_incident_node.txt1: Top incidents by nodes shows the worker nodes (hosts) with the highest number of file system or process violations.
top_incident_node.txt2: How to Use It: Nodes with high incidents can indicate a hacker has gained access and is attempting additional damage, installation, or lateral probing. Review container and host incidents for the node to determine the source, user, and commands used.

top_vulnerable_pod.txt1: Top vulnerable pods shows the containers or pods with the highest number of High severity vulnerabilities detected during the run-time scan.
top_vulnerable_pod.txt2: How to Use It: Review High CVEs for each pod to determine the risk of exploit. Make sure the service/pod is protected by network rules. Suppress reporting if the pod vulnerabilities are not a risk.

top_vulnerable_node.txt1: Top vulnerable nodes shows the nodes (hosts) with the highest number of High severity vulnerabilities detected during the run-time scan.
top_vulnerable_node.txt2: How to Use It: Review High CVEs for each node to determine the risk of exploit. Remediate if needed. Suppress reporting if the pod vulnerabilities are not a risk.

policy_mode_pod.txt1: Policy Mode Service View summarizes the number and ratio of container services in each mode Discover, Monitor and Protect. The Pod View shows the number and ratio by the number of pods (each service can deploy multiple pods).
policy_mode_pod.txt2: How to Use It: Services and Pods in Discover mode are still learning and whitelisting network behavior and will don’t have network segmentation turned on. Move services and pods into Monitor or Protect mode as soon as possible after reviewing Network Rules.

application.txt1: Application Protocols by Application conversations shows the number of conversations detected for each application protocol shown. For each of these, a application layer (Layer 7) network rule has was created to whitelist the connection. The category Others means protocols other than known protocols such as non-standard TCP connections.
application.txt2: How to Use It: Review the protocol list to make sure all common application protocols are detected and whitelisted.
application.txt3: Application Protocols by Volume shows the network activity level detected for each application protocol.
application.txt4: How to Use It: When running test traffic or in production review the activity to assess whether it looks like normal traffic patterns. High activity could indicate an attack, data breach, or misconfiguration of the application.

improveScoreModal.TITLE: Risk Review and Improvement Tool
improveScoreModal.ALL_PROTECT_MODE_DECLARE: All your service groups are under Protect mode.

summary.INSTRUCTION: The security risk score is determine by the following factors, and can be improved by this "Quick Action" wizard. You can review any of factors which you want to improve, and we can provide either a direct way to do it or advice for achieving a "GOOD" status.

serviceMode.brief_1: Review policy mode of "New Service" and running services.
serviceMode.advice_1: If your "New Service" mode is set to "Discover", your risk score will increase because new services can be deployed without protection.
serviceMode.advice_2: If you have any services in "Discover" mode, the risk score will increase (based on the percentage of all services).

exposure.brief_1: Review Ingress/Egress related network policy rules or actions.
exposure.advice_1: If you have pods which allow ingress or egress connections, the risk score will increase depending on their mode.
exposure.advice_3: If there are any ingress/egress policy violations on exposed pods it will increase the risk score.
exposure.advice_4: If there are network threats detected on the exposed pods it will increase the risk score.

privilege.brief_1: Review pods running as privileged containers.
privilege.advice_1: If you have any pods which run as privileged, the risk score will increase.

runAsRoot.advice_1: If you have any pods which run as root, the risk score will increase.

admission.advice_1: If you do not have any Admission Control rules defined and enabled, the risk score will increase because unauthorized or vulnerable pods may be deployed.

vulnerability.brief_1: Vulnerabilities have been found on pods, hosts, and/or the platform.
vulnerability.advice_1: If you have vulnerabilities on pods, the risk score will increase depending on their mode.
vulnerability.advice_3: If you have vulnerabilities on hosts, the risk score will increase.
vulnerability.advice_4: If you have vulnerabilities on the orchestration platform, the risk score will increase.

conclusion.CONGRATS_STATE: You've successfully reduced the risk score to 'Good' after your changes.
conclusion.WARNING_STATE: Your risk score is still high, so you may need to address the problem areas later.

noChangeRemind.CONGRATS_STATE: Your score has not been changed, but it is still 'Good'
noChangeRemind.WARNING_STATE: Your score has not been changed, please address the problem areas in order to improve it.

serviceMode.DESCRIPTION: Set the "New Services Mode" to "Monitor"or "Protect" and switch the mode of running services to  "Monitor" or "Protect" if you believe the policy rules are stable (from auto-learning or manual configuration).

exposure.DESCRIPTION_1: Switch the mode of running services to "Monitor" or "Protect" to protect against unauthorized network connections, processes, or file system activity.
exposure.DESCRIPTION_2: Review and clear the network threats history, if these are not considered to be current threats or can be ignored.
exposure.DESCRIPTION_3: Review and clear the violation history, if these are acceptable rule violations or can be ignored. If violations should be allowed, then also make sure there is now a whitelist rule in Policy -> Network Rules to allow future connections.
exposure.DESCRIPTION_4: Review ingress or egress connections to see if they should not be allowed. If they should not be, remove the whitelist rule allowing them or create a deny rule in Policy -> Network Rules. Then clear the session history to reduce the risk score.

privilege.DESCRIPTION: Stop pods which are running as privileged containers.

runAsRoot.DESCRIPTION: Stop pods which are running as root containers.

admission.DESCRIPTION: Add Admission Control rules with 'deny' actions using a specific criteria in order to block unauthorized or vulnerable image deployments.

vulnerability.DESCRIPTION: Review the vulnerabilities analysis results and fix high risk images, pods, hosts, or orchestration platform to remediate high urgency vulnerabilities.
vulnerability.INSTRUCTION_1: For high risk pods/hosts/platform, please review them in "Secutiry risks -> Vulnerabilities"
vulnerability.INSTRUCTION_2: For major vulnerabilites, please review the following tables (for the top 10 impactful vulnerabilities)

mode.LEARN_EVALUATE: We’ve automatically created rules for your application(s). No new rules will be automatically created while in Monitor mode. New rules can be added manually in Policy/Rules.
mode.LEARN_ENFORCE: We’ve automatically created rules for your application(s). No new rules will be automatically created while in Protect mode. New rules can be added manually in Policy/Rules. In Protect mode conversations which are detected as violations of your security policy will be denied (blocked).
mode.EVALUATE_ENFORCE: In Protect mode conversations which are detected as violations of your security policy will be denied (blocked).

tip.LEARNING: Discover behavior of applications and services and automatically build policy rules
tip.EVALUATING: Monitor real-time behavior, log activities and detect potential violations
tip.ENFORCING: Prevent violations and attacks during run-time

The current cluster will be promoted to be the Primary Cluster. You will be logged out automatically, then required to log back in, and your role will be changed to be a Federated Administrator.

  * Note: The system time needs to be synced.

joining.failure: Failed to join the Primary Cluster.

server.PRE_DESC: To request a license, please contact
server.APPLY_DESC: Enter code received from NeuVector support
server.POST_DESC: , we will contact you with your License Code.

register.NAME: Licensee
register.EMAIL_REQUIRED: You must provide an valid e-mail address.
register.NUM_HOSTS_REQUIRED: You must set number of hosts!
register.NUM_MONTHS_REQUIRED: You must set number of months!
register.INVALID_MULTI_CLUSTER_LIMIT: Please enter a number no more than 1000
register.INVALID_PHONE: (###) ###-#### - Please enter a valid phone number.

message.GET_LICENSE_ERR: Error happened when getting license information

setting.TITLE: System Settings
setting.CLUSTER_COMMENT: Used to identify the cluster in notifications
setting.ZERODRIFT_COMMENT: Automated process and file protections based on drift detection from original image
setting.SEND_SYSLOG_PER_CVE: Send individual syslog events per CVE
setting.IMPORT_NOTICE: Importing policy will overwrite groups and rules, importing all will overwrite policy and all users and passwords and settings such as SYSLOG and other configurations.
setting.QUEUE_DESC: No file selected. Please add a file.
setting.SUPPORT_IN_PROGRESS: Collecting logs for Manager, Controller and Enforcer...
setting.AUTH_BY_OPENSHIFT: Authenticate using OpenShift RBAC’s or Rancher’s
setting.PROXY_HINT: Proxy for accessing external services (such as webhooks, registry servers). Proxy is also supported for communications among NeuVector clusters in the same federation when direct access between clusters is not allowed.
setting.UNUSED_GROUP_HINT: Groups with no members (e.g. pods/containers) will be deleted automatically if they remain unused for this amount of time.
setting.ENABLED_CPATH_OK: Controller control path debug is enabled successfully.
setting.DISABLED_CPATH_OK: Controller control path debug is disabled successfully.
setting.ENABLED_CPATH_NG: Error happens when enabling controller control path debug.
setting.DISABLED_CPATH_NG: Error happens when disabling controller control path debug.
setting.ENFORCERS_HINT: Select enforcers to include their support log if necessary. Up to {{maxSlectedEnforcer}} enforcers can be selected.
setting.MAX_SELECTED_ENFORCER_HINT: Please select no more than {{maxSlectedEnforcer}} enforcers for support log.

webhook.NAME: Name
webhook.LEAVE_PAGE: Do you want to leave the page without saving configration setting?
webhook.DELETE_CONFIRM: Do you want to remove webhook - {{name}}

message.IP_INVALID: That doesn't look like a valid ip.
message.URL_INVALID: That doesn't look like a valid url.
message.GET_SYS_LOG_ERR: Error happened when getting system settings
message.UPLOAD_FINISH: File uploaded successfully. Please wait for a moment when system is importing the data. System will logout automatically. please login again after it finished.

description.USERS: Add, rename and manage users, permissions and password profile.
description.CONFIGURATION: Enable Syslog, Webhooks and queue file imports and exports.
description.LDAP: Configure an LDAP directory or Microsoft active directory to enable authentication of users.
description.SAML: Configure single sign on using SAML.
description.OPENID: Configure single sign on using OpenID Connect.

head.TITLE: LDAP/AD Setting
head.GUIDE: The setting below configure an LDAP directory or Microsoft active directory which will be used to authenticate user.

test.TITLE: Check LDAP/AD connection
test.NOTE: Input user and password to check!

ldap.ROLE_DOMAIN_INSTRUCTION: Select access role in the table, then edit namespace list under the table
ldap.DM_ROLE_HINT: Add namespaces for which this user has {{role}} privileges
ldap.GROUP_MEMBER_ATTR_HINT: The attribute field to use when loading the group members from the group.
ldap.GROUP_MEMBER_ATTR_MESSAGE: Please enter a valid group member attribute
ldap.USERNAME_ATTR_HINT: The attribute field to use when loading the user.
ldap.USERNAME_ATTR_MESSAGE: Please enter a valid username attribute
ldap.ADMIN_HINT: Add LDAP/AD groups which map to NeuVector admin
ldap.READER_HINT: Add LDAP/AD groups which map to NeuVector reader
ldap.CI_HINT: Add LDAP/AD groups which map to NeuVector CI Integration
ldap.BASE_DN_HINT: Root node in LDAP/AD from which to search users and groups. e.g. dc=neuvector, dc=com
ldap.BASE_DN_MESSAGE: Please enter a valid base DN.
ldap.GP_ROLE_HINT: Add groups for which this user has {{role}} privileges

message.GET_LDAP_ERR: Error happened when getting LDAP configuration

head.TITLE: SAML Setting
head.GUIDE: The setting below configure single sign on using SAML.

okta.ADMIN_HINT: Add SAML groups which map to NeuVector admin
okta.READER_HINT: Add SAML groups which map to NeuVector reader
okta.CI_HINT: Add SAML groups which map to NeuVector CI Integration

message.GET_SAML_ERR: Error happened when getting SAML configuration

head.TITLE: OpenID Connect Setting
head.GUIDE: The setting below configure single sign on using OpenID Connect.

openId.ADMIN_HINT: Add OpenID Connect groups which map to NeuVector admin
openId.READER_HINT: Add OpenID Connect groups which map to NeuVector reader
openId.CI_HINT: Add OpenID Connect groups which map to NeuVector CI Integration
